headline: 'Big Short' investor Burry turned more bullish on second quarter
summary: Michael Burry's Scion Asset Management ended the first quarter more bullish on companies across different sectors and geographies, a securities filing showed on Thursday, after betting against Chinese companies previously as the Trump administration considered imposing tariffs. Burry, known as the "Big Short" investor for his prescient calls ahead of the 2008 U.S. housing market crash, placed bets that benefit from a rise in share prices. The call options convey the right to buy shares at a set price in the future.

headline: Sportsman's Warehouse, Lululemon, Williams-Sonoma, Bath and Body Works, and America's Car-Mart Shares Are Falling, What You Need To Know
summary: A number of stocks fell in the afternoon session after a hotter-than-expected wholesale inflation report fueled concerns about slowing consumer spending. The market was rattled by a Labor Department report showing the Producer Price Index (PPI), a measure of wholesale inflation, jumped 0.9% in July, significantly exceeding economists' expectations of a 0.2% rise. This was the largest monthly increase since March 2022, reigniting worries that businesses will be forced to pass higher costs on to c

headline: A Great Day in the Stoke Presented by Lexus Returns to Surf City USA for Fourth Annual Celebration of Black Surf Culture on September 27
summary: A Great Day in the Stoke (AGDITS) Presented by Lexus - a trailblazing surf competition and cultural festival celebrating Black surf culture - returns to Surf City USA for its fourth annual event on September 27. Open to all, the free festival showcases the top Black surf talent from around the world and promotes connection, water safety and health & wellness through activations with partners including Lexus, Lululemon and more.

headline: North America Athletic Wear Market Trends and Company Analysis Report 2025-2033 Featuring NIKE, New Balance, Under Armour, Lululemon, Adidas, Patagonia, The North Face, Alo, PUMA, and Columbia
summary: The North America Athletic Wear Market, valued at $25.44 billion in 2024, is projected to grow at a 7.48% CAGR, reaching $48.63 billion by 2033. Key growth drivers include increasing health consciousness, active lifestyles, and innovation in performance materials. The surge in athleisure and sustainable apparel trends also fuels demand. Product categories span top wear, bottom wear, and base layers, with leading brands like Nike, Adidas, and Lululemon capitalizing on market opportunities across

summary: Investors are getting pessimistic about this beloved athleisure brand, which could make the stock a buy.
